sub_topic: Calculation of entropy change for a chemical reaction
message_1: What is the change in entropy when 2 moles of hydrogen gas react with 1 mole of oxygen gas to form 2 moles of water vapor at 298 K and 1 atm pressure?
message_2:
To calculate the change in entropy for this reaction, we need to find the difference between the entropy of the products and the entropy of the reactants. The reaction is:

2 H₂(g) + O₂(g) → 2 H₂O(g)

First, we need to find the standard molar entropies (S°) for each substance involved in the reaction. The standard molar entropies at 298 K are:

S°(H₂) = 130.6 J/mol·K
S°(O₂) = 205.1 J/mol·K
S°(H₂O) = 188.8 J/mol·K

Now, we can calculate the change in entropy (ΔS°) for the reaction:

ΔS° = [2 × S°(H₂O)] - [2 × S°(H₂) + S°(O₂)]

ΔS° = [2 × 188.8 J/mol·K] - [2 × 130.6 J/mol·K + 205.1 J/mol·K]

ΔS° = [377.6 J/mol·K] - [466.3 J/mol·K]

ΔS° = -88.7 J/mol·K

The change in entropy for this reaction is -88.7 J/mol·K.
